hero.title: Mishpacha – A Family for Orphans in Israel
hero.subtitle: Comprehensive support for orphans in Israel – emotional, educational, legal, and social
hero.text:
No child should have to face loss alone.

Mishpacha is a national organization supporting orphans in Israel and their families through emotional, educational, legal, and social care.

We are here to walk alongside them, to strengthen, and to ensure that no child or young adult is ever left alone.

about.title: Who We Are and Why We Founded Mishpacha
intro: Mishpacha was born from personal experience and a deep understanding that orphaned youth in Israel need real guidance during the most critical years of their lives: adolescence, military service, and the first steps into independent adulthood.

We are not just another welfare organization, but a supportive family for youth and young adults after loss, standing with them at a complex crossroads of identity, decision-making, and future, often without a full family safety net.

Our work focuses on personal guidance, emotional resilience, and building practical life skills, serving orphaned youth, soldiers, and young adults at the beginning of their independent journey, alongside volunteers and professionals who seek to be part of a deep and lasting solution.

pillars.text: Ongoing mentoring and close support for orphaned youth, soldiers, and discharged young adults during the most formative years of life.

pillars.title: Life Skills & Independence
pillars.text: Emotional strengthening, guidance, and practical tools for military service and building stable, independent adult lives.

services.title: What We Do for Orphans in Israel
services.intro: The organization works to provide orphans with stability, practical tools, and long-term guidance — from the initial moment of loss to full independence.

items.title: Financial Support and Education
items.text: Scholarships and tuition assistance, funding for courses and professional training, and guidance in critical financial decisions — enabling progress without financial barriers.

items.title: Emotional and Psychological Support
items.text: Professional emotional care, support groups, and empowerment workshops — helping cope with loss, strengthen personal resilience, and build self-confidence.

items.title: Personal Mentorship and Guidance
items.text: Ongoing connection with dedicated mentors, career guidance, and personal support — so important decisions are not made alone.

items.title: Rights Assistance and Support with Authorities
items.text: Support in accessing benefits, bureaucratic and legal guidance, and representation with relevant authorities — ensuring that legal rights are fully exercised.

items.title: Community, Belonging, and Social Connection
items.text: Building a supportive social framework through gatherings, trips, and activities — reducing loneliness and fostering a sense of belonging.

items.title: Housing Support and Foster Families
items.text: Assistance in finding housing solutions, guidance for foster families, and support throughout adoption processes — creating a stable and secure home.

story.title: Personal Story: A Voice from the Field
story.quote: When my father passed away, I was 14 and didn't know where to turn. Mishpacha didn’t just help me financially – they gave me a second family...
story.note: Stories like Jonathan's are why we wake up every morning.

orphanWeek.title: Israeli Orphans’ Families Week
orphanWeek.intro: A national week dedicated to placing the issue of orphanhood at the center of educational, community, and public discourse – grounded in recognition, responsibility, and resilience.
orphanWeek.aboutToggle: Click for a full explanation of the week
orphanWeek.aboutText:
In Israel, thousands of children, adolescents, and young adults have lost a parent, yet the experience of orphanhood often remains invisible and excluded from public discourse. Israeli Orphans’ Families Week was created to change this – not out of pity, but out of recognition of the lived reality of orphans and the shared responsibility of society as a whole to accompany, support, and include them.

The week creates an educational, community, and national continuum: safe dialogue in schools, increased public awareness, policy advancement, and community support – with the aim of strengthening visibility, belonging, and resilience for orphaned families and for Israeli society as a whole.

days.label: Sunday – Opening and Recognition
days.title: National Opening Event
days.text: The opening day is dedicated to public and official recognition of the lived reality of orphaned children and adolescents. It marks the placement of the issue at the center of public attention through personal testimonies, remarks by education and welfare professionals, and public representatives, alongside a call for sustained social responsibility.

days.label: Monday–Wednesday – Education and Awareness
days.title: Educational Dialogue and Raising Awareness
days.text: These days are devoted to educational and community-based work: lesson plans in schools, age-appropriate classroom discussions, community activities, and media exposure. The emphasis is on understanding, empathy, and providing tools for becoming a supportive society – without pity and without silencing.

days.label: Thursday – Policy and Responsibility
days.title: Advancing Policy and Rights
days.text: This day focuses on the systemic dimensions of orphanhood: meetings with government ministries, local authorities, and professional stakeholders, aimed at advancing recognition, rights, and sustained support frameworks for orphaned children and adults.

days.label: Friday–Saturday – Community and Belonging
days.title: Community Activities and Strengthening Belonging
days.text: The closing of the week is dedicated to the community: gatherings, cultural activities, and events that strengthen connection, visibility, and belonging, and emphasize that orphanhood is not loneliness – but a lived reality that can and must be accompanied together.

orphanWeek.note: Israeli Orphans’ Families Week is a first step in an ongoing process of educational, social, and systemic change – for orphans and for a more sensitive, responsible, and inclusive society.
